awd_titl_txt: Microwave Traps and Atom Interferometry with AC Zeeman Potentials
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop and characterize atom interferometers based on ultracold trapped atoms on an atom chip. Atom interferometers are the most sensitive force measuring devices ever constructed and are well suited for precision measurements and detection of electric and magnetic fields, gravity, and inertial forces, such as accelerations and rotations. Applications of atom interferometers include inertial navigation in a GPS-denied environment, remote sensing of underground structures, measuring atom-surface forces, and searching for deviations of the gravitational force from the inverse square law. While most atom interferometers operate with freely propagating atoms, one of the main scientific goals of this project is to develop and evaluate atom interferometers based on trapped atoms. Furthermore, the project will control these atoms using AC Zeeman potentials, a novel and little explored quantum control mechanism for applying forces on atoms using microwave fields generated in the vicinity of an atom chip. Graduate and undergraduate student researchers will be trained in atom interferometry, ultracold atom technologies, microwave engineering, and micro-fabrication techniques, as well as in the broadly enabling sciences of atomic and optical physics.

More specifically, this project will construct ultracold trapped atom interferometers that are capable of long phase integration times with well localized, positionable atomic packets. These trapped atom interferometers will be spin-dependent so that the two arms of the interferometer have atoms in different quantum spin states. The spin-dependence will enable the interferometer to use atoms in many different spatial states so that it can employ ultracold thermal atoms or degenerate fermions, which are expected to suppress atom-atom interactions. The project will use AC Zeeman potentials generated by microwave near-fields from an atom chip to implement the spin-dependent forces and traps for the interferometer. Notably, the project will design and micro-fabricate a microwave atom chip for efficient generation of AC Zeeman potentials. An important objective of this project is to develop and characterize AC Zeeman traps and potentials, and thus evaluate them for inclusion in the toolbox of ultracold atomic physics techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project successfully developed the world's first radio frequency (RF) trap for ultracold neutral atoms. This new type of trap is an important step towards the development of a trapped atom interferometer on an atom chip with the ultimate goal of measuring inertial forces (i.e., accelerations, rotations, and gravity) and electromagnetic forces.

 

Intellectual Merit

The project's long-term objective is the development of a trapped atom interferometer using RF and microwave traps (i.e., AC Zeeman traps) on an atom chip. To this end, over its formal duration, the project helped to achieve the following milestones:

1) The research team designed and demonstrated the world's first RF trap for neutral atoms. This spin-dependent trap operates on an atom chip, and it can trap any magnetic spin state of an atom.

2) Furthermore, the team showed that the atoms in this RF trap can be cooled by forced evaporation with the application of a RF or microwave "knife."

3) The project demonstrated theoretically that AC Zeeman traps on an atom chip should be substantially smoother than their traditional micro-magnetic chip trap counterparts generated by DC currents. An experiment to measure this improvement of trap smoothness was initiated.

4) The project designed a microwave atom chip for operation up to 10 GHz based on microstrip transmission lines. As part of this work, the team pursued the development of a number of building blocks for this new type of chip, including a microwave substrate based on aluminum nitride and a broadband cable-to-chip coupler based on a tapered substrate. An ultra-low phase noise microwave source with phase continuous digital frequency and phase control was developed to drive the chip.

5) Finally, the project developed a spin-dependent atom interferometer based on ultracold atoms confined in a laser dipole trap. The two arms of the interferometer can be separated using a microwave AC Zeeman force generated by an atom chip. This work is a first step towards an interferometer based on two distinct microwave AC Zeeman traps.

 

Broader Impact

The project provided broad training to graduate and undergraduate researchers in atomic physics, laser optics, microwave engineering, ultracold atom techniques, and quantum information science. More specifically, the project trained and graduated one PhD student and helped support the training of two additional PhD students. A junior graduate student was also trained. At the undergraduate level, the project helped train a number of student researchers, including 13 senior thesis students (seven women) and one summer researcher.
